how is power converted into electricity?  Define power.
Electricity is the flow of electrons through a substance.
In the United States, electricity can be generated through coal/fossil fuel burning plants, nuclear power plants, wind(mills), and solar energy collection.

In fossil fuel and nuclear plants, they use the furnace and nuclear reactor to heat up water in order to turn a turbine, which spins around an electromagnet to generate electricity. There is much loss of energy through this process because much of the energy used to heat the water is lost through convection.  In windmills, the wind directly turns the turbine, so there is not as much loss, plus, it is a renewable resource.

Math equation that I need help solving? If I have $25.00 and want 3 parts blue sand which costs $11.49 per pound and 1 part yellow sand which costs $7.99  per pound, how much of each can I buy? What is the equation for this. How could you teach me to learn how to do equations like this from YAHOO! ANSWERS if that is possible? Maybe some little trick I can take with me into Finals? Still need equation though. Your mixture has four parts: three parts Blue Sand and one part Yellow Sand.

Assume that you have 100 pounds of this mixture.  It would contain 75 pounds Blue Sand and 25 pounds Yellow Sand.

75 pounds of Blue sand costs $861.75 (75 * 11.49)
25 pounds of Yellow sand costs $199.75 (25 * 7.99)

So 100 pounds of the mixture costs $1061.50 (861.75 + 199.75)

At this rate, one pound costs $10.615.

With $25, you can afford 2.355 pounds of the mixture (25 / 10.615)

Can there exist a spherical magnet? I have a query regarding the above question. If there exists a spherical magnet, then how do u locate its poles? As earth is considered to be a magnet, its poles are located at its 2 flat(assumed) surfaces with assumption that a needle passes through its poles. Can anyone help me in answering this question? In high-energy physics, medical treatments, and space detections, quadrupole field distributions and sextupole field distributions are often required over a large spherical volume. Traditionally, these fields can be generated with cylindrical magnets. In comparison with cylindrical magnets, the spherical magnets have the advantages of smaller values of inductances, lower energy storage, and less magnetic flux leakage. The basic method derives from the target field approach that has been used to solve many of the inverse electromagnetic problems. 

Calculation:

The geomagnetic poles or geocentric dipole, can be computed from the first three Gauss coefficients from a main field model, such as the WMM or IGRF. Based on the current WMM model, the 2005 location of the geomagnetic north pole is 79.74°N and 71.78°W and the geomagnetic south pole is 79.74°S and 108.22°E. 

The magnetic poles or dip pole are computed from all the Gauss coefficients using an iterative method. Based on the current WMM model, the 2005 location of the north magnetic pole is 83.21°N and 118.32°W and the south magnetic pole is 64.53°S and 137.86°E.

The location of the center of the eccentric dipole, sometimes known as the magnetic center, computed using the first eight Gauss coefficients for 2005.0, is at approximately (r, φ´, λ) = (552 km, 22.2°N, 141.6°E). 

The task of locating the principal magnetic pole by instrument is difficult for many reasons; the large area over which the dip or inclination (I) is nearly 90 degrees, the pole areas are not fixed points, but move tens to hundreds of kilometers because of daily variations and magnetic storms, and finally, the polar areas are relatively inaccessible to survey crews (map of North and South polar wander - courtesy of Dr. John Quinn, U.S. Geological Survey retired). The Geological Survey of Canada keeps track of the North Magnetic Pole, which is slowly drifting across the Canadian Arctic, by periodically carrying out magnetic surveys to redetermine the Pole's location. The most recent survey, completed in May, 2001, determined an updated position for the Pole and established that it is moving approximately northwest at 40 km per year.

What is the empirical formula for the compound in the question below ? A certain compound was found to have a molar mass of   32.042 g.   A   4.078 g   sample of this compound was burned in pure oxygen gas. The measured amount of   CO2   produced was   5.601 g,   while that of   H2O   was   4.586 g.   No other products were produced in the reaction.  if needed the # of moles of   hydrogen in the original sample that underwent combustion is 0.509 1) determine the mass of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen.
carbon: 5.601 g x (12 / 44) = 1.528 g
hydrogen: 4.586 g x (2 / 18) = 0.510 g
oxygen: 4.078 - 1.528 - .510 = 2.040 g

2) convert to moles.
carbon: 1.528 / 12 = 0.127 mol
hydrogen: 0.510 / 1 = 0.510 mol
oxygen: 2.040 / 16 = 0.128 mol

3) divide each molar amount by the lowest value to obtain small integers
carbon: 0.127 / 0.127 = 1
hydrogen: 0.510  / 0.127 = 4
oxygen: 0.128 / 0.127 = 1

The empirical formula of the substance is (CH4O)n
The atomic masses add up to 32, which is also the molar mass of the compound. Therefore n=1 and we find CH4O

how capacitor work with relay in a air-condition to operate compressure?  A motor requires about 6 times as much current to start as it does to run, so a static-capacitor phase converter must have some means of switching a large group of capacitors in and out during motor starting.\n  \nA typical unit uses a potential-type motor starting relay  to regulate the larger start capacitor, while a smaller (in value) capacitor provides continuous power to run the motor. As the motor speed increases, the potential relay removes the start capacitor from the circuit, and the motor operates.

What is the difference between? Biomedical sciences and biomedical engineering? Biomedical engineering-
Biomedical engineering (BME) is the application of engineering principles and techniques to the medical field. It combines the design and problem solving expertise of engineering with the medical expertise of physicians to help improve patient health care and the quality of life of healthy individuals. As a relatively new discipline, much of the work in biomedical engineering consists of research and development, covering an array of fields: bioinformatics, medical imaging, image processing, physiological signal processing, biomechanics, biomaterials and bioengineering, systems analysis, 3-D modeling, etc. Examples of concrete applications of biomedical engineering are the development and manufacture of biocompatible prostheses, medical devices, diagnostic devices and imaging equipment such as MRIs and EEGs, and pharmaceutical drugs.
Biomedical sciences-
Health science is the discipline of applied science which deals with human and animal health. There are two parts to health science: the study, research, and knowledge of health and the application of that knowledge to improve health, cure diseases, and understanding how humans and animals function. Research builds primarily on the pure sciences of biology, chemistry, and physics as well as social sciences (for example medical sociology). Other fields which made an exceptionally significant contribution to the health sciences include biochemistry, biotechnology, engineering, epidemiology, genetics, nursing, pharmacology, pharmacy, public health, and medicine. The health sciences industry, a multi-billion dollar business, is a subset of the life sciences, medical care, and diagnosis industries.

Acid rain problems--> acid/base? Acid rain, caused by pollution from cars and industries, is a major environ. problem. Acid rain that falls in areas where the rock is mainly limestone does not disrupt the ecosystem as much as acid rain that falls in an area where the rock is mainly granite. Why is this? DOes it have anything to do with acids and bases?? Yes it has something to do with acids.

Limestone is CaCO3 deposits. If you look at the acid-base reaction between an acid and CaCO3 you can see that the carbonate ion favors being protonated and because of the fact that it's protonated state is very unstable it readily becomes water and CO2 gas. 

2 H+ + CO3 2- ---> H2CO3 ---> H2O + CO2

These two products of the reaction are very healthy for environments. However, since this reaction doesn't occur in areas of mostly granite, these bi-products aren't produced leading to the acid having a more detrimental affect on the surrounding environment.

Name the three types of seismic waves and the direction they move land?  Seismic waves are basically waves of energy caused by the sudden breaking of rock within the earth or even a massive explosion such as a volcano. They are the energy that travels through the earth and this energy will then get recorded on seismographs.

The first kind of seismic waves are known P wave or primary waves. This is the fastest kind of seismic wave. The P wave can move through solid rock and fluids, like water or the liquid layers of the earth. It pushes and pulls the rock as it moves through just like sound waves push and pull the air. If  you have ever heard a  thunder and have also heard the windows rattle at the same time this is an example. The windows rattle because the sound waves were pushing and pulling on the window glass much like P waves push and pull on rock. Usually we only feel the bump and rattle of these waves.

The second type of seismic wave is the S wave or secondary wave, which is the second wave you feel in an earthquake. An S wave is slower than a P wave and can only move through solid rock. This wave moves rock up and down, or side-to-side.

These 2 types of waves are known a body waves, next come surface waves or L waves. L waves exist because of the Earth’s surface.  They are largest at the surface and decrease in amplitude with depth. L waves are known only to move along the surface of the earth. There speeds vary depending on the material, rock or soil, forming the surface. These waves cause the surface features such as buildings to move from side-to-side.

More?? Less??...Same? An airplane flies in a straight line from Airport A to airport B, then back in a srtaight line from B to A.  It travels with a constant engine speed and there is no wind.  Will its travel time for the same round trip be greater, less or the same if, throughout both flights, and at the same engine speed, a constant wind blows from A to B. It will be more. Mathematically:

no wind case:

Let the distance from A to B = d
And let the speed of the plane without wind = v
Since distance/speed = time, in the case with no wind the time for the return trip =  d/v + d/v = 2d/v

Wind case:

Let d,v be as above, and let the wind speed blowing from A to B = w. The planes wind-aided speed = v+w and it's wind reduced speed is v-w. The time for the return trip is now:

d /(v+w) + d /(v-w) = (d(v-w)+d(v+w))/(v^2 - w^2)

This simplifies to:

2dv /(v^2 - w^2) compared to 2d /v for the no wind case.

The ratio of the no wind case to the wind case is:

v^2 / (v^2 - w^2)

We see that if w > 0, this ratio will be greater than 1, which means the return trip will take more time if there is a wind.

If i was to Major in Biology what type of career would that lead me too??  Teaching is not the only option; here are some of the Careers I know of:


1) Pathologists concentrate on the effects of disease on cells, tissues, and organs of plants and animals.

2) Physiologists specialize in the study of the life functions of plant and animals. These functions include growth, respiration, and reproduction.

3) Geneticists study heredity and how traits or inherited characteristics vary in all forms of life. They expand our knowledge about how traits originate and are passed on from one generation to another.

4) Anatomists study the structure of living things, ranging from single-celled plants and animals to human beings and redwood trees.

5) Botanists are biologists who specialize in the study of plants.

6) Microbiologists are those who work with microscopic forms of plant and animal life, such as bacteria, fungi, and viruses.

7) Nutritionists study how food is used and changed into energy. They examine ways in which living tissue is built and repaired by its use of vitamins, minerals, proteins, and other nutrients. 

8) Pharmacologists study the effects of drugs and other substances, such as poisons and dusts, on living organisms.

9) Biochemists specialize in the study of the chemistry of living organisms. 

10) Biophysicists concentrate on the atomic structure and the electrical and mechanical energy of cells and organisms.

11) Ecologists are life scientists who study the relationship between plants and animals and their environment. 

12) Marine biologists, or biological oceanographers, study the organisms living in the ocean. 

13) Zoologists are biologists who study animals.

14) Taxonomists, or systematists, specialize in the identification, description, and classification of animals and determines how a given species fits into the scheme of nature.

Question  in Physics? A straight rope with mass 0 is lying on a smooth surface (no friction). Two poeple start to move from the center of the rope to different directions with the same velocities. When they get to the edges of the rope, they grasp it, and this causes them to stop moving (the rope cannot be stretched to longer length) - all the energy was gone. Another scene is that the rope is lying vertically to it's previous position, and the two poeple come from different directions horizontally and grap the two edges (they move, before the grasping in two parallel tracks). This causes them to perform a circular movement, without affecting their velocities' size (the direction is changed) - so the energy does not change. What is the physical explanation for these both scenes regarding the energy? what your calling energy is really Net Force.  or Mass x Acceleration.  

in the first example, the energy wasn't gone, if you assume that the people have the same mass and were traveling at teh same velocities when they reached teh end then the net force acting on the system is 0 because the force (ma) of the first person is equeal to the force of the second person, so they cancel.  

in the second example, a centrepedial force, or force towards teh center, is being applied from teh rope on the people holding it.  this causes the direction of their velocity to change.  using dot products we can find teh work done, which is change in kinetic energy.  you will find that the work done on one person is equal and opposite to the work done on the other.

What happens to all of the matter and light that enters a black hole? Does the black hole continue to increase in mass and increase the gravitational affect?  Or does all that stuff get shot out in another direction?  Do black holes ever die? And if so, what happens to them? "...Does the black hole continue to increase in mass and increase the gravitational affect?..."
We haven't been studying black holes long enough yet to determine if their mass does increase from all the material being drawn in. Theoretically it would.

"...does all that stuff get shot out in another direction?..."
Exactly what happens to material that disappears beyond the event horizon of black holes isn't known for sure because there's no way science can observe what goes on there. A few speculations persist about so-called  'white holes,' the drain of black holes where everything re-appears in another universe or dimension.

"...Do black holes ever die? And if so, what happens to them?..."
Again, science doesn't know because the observational evidence just isn't there. However, Stephen Hawking has developed a workable theory showing that over great lengths of time black holes can actually radiate some of their energy and in time would evaporate.

does the wind that goes over the wing of a plane create a vacuum that sucks the plane into the air? i was watching the magic of flight and it showed a part where it said the wing that goes over the plane creates a kind of vacuum which sucks the plane skyward than the wind goes under the wing to keep it in the air. Air travelling above the wing is at a higher velocity than that travelling below the wing. High v = low pressure (Bernoulli's eqn) therefore the higher pressure under the wing generates a resultant force towards the lower pressure and pushes the wing upward, creating lift.

I use TMB for ELISA, dissolved in DMSO. However, it's poorly soluble at buffer pH 4.5. How do I overcome it? TMB = tetramethylbenzidine,
DMSO = dimethylsulphoxide The pH of DMSO should be around 7.  I would dissolve the TMB at a very high concentration (100-1000 times the concentration you would like as the final) in DMSO at pH 7 and then add just a small amount of this concentrate to your sample at pH4.5.  Otherwise, you could dissolve the TMB in DMSO at pH 7 and then titrate the pH of the TMB/DMSO solution down to 4.5 using HCl.

Another possibility would be to try adding a lower concentration of TMB to your sample.  A protocol for TMB usage in ELISA can be found on the Molecular Probes website (https://www.invitrogen.com/content/sfs/manuals/00-2023.pdf)

what is the chemcal relationship between paint and chemistry?  Paint is an oxidation preventor, it creates a layer on the top of many metals (such as those used on bridges) preventing the actual metal from reacting with the oxygen in the air, thus weakening the metal by converting some of its mass to rust (ferrous oxide).

find the INT of (2x^2 + x + 7) divided by (x^2+4)^2 dx? how to do ?? Using partial fractions :
(2x^2 + x + 7)/ (x^2+4)^2 = a/(x^2+4) +(b x + c)/((x^2+4)^2
Equating the two sides we get   a=2 , b=1  , c=-1
So the integration will be :
INT 2/(x^2+4)dx + INT (x-1)* (x^2+4)^(-2)dx
= atan (x/2) + INT 1/2*[(2x -2)](x^2+4)^(-2)
= atan (x/2)+ 1/2 [INT (x^2+4)^(-2)*2x dx] 
- INT [(x^2+4)^(-2)] dx
= atan (x/2)+ 1/2 [ -1/(x^2+4)] - INT3
Now to calculate INT3 :
Let x = 2 tan y   --> y = atan x/2
dx = 2 sec^2 y  dy
(x^2 + 4)^2 = (4 tan^2 y + 4)^2 = 16 sec^4 y
INT3 = INT [1/(16 sec^4(y)) * 2 sec^2 y dy
INT3 = INT ( 1/8 * cos^2 y )dy 
INT3 = INT [1/8 * 1/2 * ( 1 + cos 2y)] dy
INT3 = 1/16 [ y + 1/2 sin 2y ]
INT3 = 1/16 [ atan x/2 +  sin y cos y ]
INT3 = 1/16 [ atan x/2 + 2x/(4+x^2)]
INT3 = 1/16 atan x/2 + x/(8*(4+x^2)
the final result :
= atan (x/2)+ 1/2 [-1/(x^2+4)]- 1/16 atan x/2 - x/(8*(4+x^2)
= 15/16 * atan (x/2) -1/[2(x^2+4)] - x/[8*(4+x^2) + C
= 15/16 * atan (x/2) - ((4 + x)/(8*(4+x^2))+ C

why is venus a important planet? the planet venus is a project im doing at school i need help with this question ppl. This section summarizes advances in our understanding of Venus since 1978 and outstanding problems that require resolution by future missions. The decade following the 1978 report witnessed the acquisition of the first geophysical data relevant to the planet's interior. The Pioneer Venus radar altimeter provided a global topographic map, and radio tracking of the orbiter supplied gravity data over limited regions. In contrast to Earth, Venus's gravity and topography are highly correlated, and interpretations of the combined data may involve mantle and lithosphere dynamical processes peculiar to Venus. The Pioneer Venus magnetometer placed a strict upper limit on any internally generated global magnetic field; the implications of this for the planet's internal structure and theories of the geodynamo are profound and include the possibility that the core is completely liquid. 

The Soviet Venera 15 and 16 radar missions, as well as high-resolution Earth-based radar observations, have revealed a complex tectonic history for the Venus surface. There are unique features visible in these images that could have important implications for internal processes. Although the impact crater record provides a broad constraint on surface ages, limited resolution (1 to 2 km) has prevented identification of the complete record with certainty. The Magellan mission should provide resolution sufficient to characterize the cratering history and to search for a possible relic crater population prior to climatic instability. The mission should also test hypotheses about the timing, style, and rate of surface-modification processes including erosion, possible fossil river beds, volcanic resurfacing, and perhaps plate tectonics. 

Experiments to determine major element composition of surface rocks were performed by seven of the Soviet Venera landers. The elemental inventories are all consistent with two types of basalts: high-potassium basalt near a suspected impact feature and tholeiitic basalts in the lowland plains, similar to ocean floor basalts on Earth. 

Noble gas abundances in the atmosphere of Venus were measured by the Pioneer Venus and Venera probes, but the data contain serious conflicts and are subject to profound differences of interpretation. The deuterium abundance in the atmosphere was tentatively determined from the 1978 Pioneer Venus data to be 0.016. This elevated value has been a prime driver for the argument that the planet has lost a massive amount of water over the age of the solar system, although an alternative interpretation involving comet impacts is also viable. In addition, the reported abundance of water in the atmosphere has a very peculiar altitude profile when the Pioneer Venus and Venera measurements are combined. Since the water and the deuterium abundances are key quantities in understanding the evolution of the atmosphere and the planet's surface, improved abundances and height profiles are essential. 

Global changes in the composition of the Venus atmosphere have recently been shown to occur on short time scales, on the order of months or years. Analysis indicates that the global average abundance of SO2 in the visible-part of the atmosphere decreased tenfold between 1978 and 1983, perhaps as result of the recovery of the atmosphere from a massive volcanic eruption. 

Pioneer Venus provided important information on ionospheric and solar wind interactions, atmospheric thermal structure, zonal and meridional circulation, and planetary-scale waves and tides. The Soviet VEGA balloons collected additional information about the dynamics of the atmosphere of cloud level. 

SCIENTIFIC OBJECTIVES

Measurements from Pioneer Venus, Venera; VEGA, and ground-based investigations have provided a quantitative data base but have also raised fundamental issues concerning the planet's interior, surface, and atmosphere that demand further study.

All transuranic elements (elements with an atomic number greater than 92) are unstable, some of their isotopes more so than others, and they aren't found in nature, only as a result of bombardment in particle accelerators or as byproducts of nuclear fission reactors or atomic bombs.

explain hooke's law?  In physics, Hooke's law of elasticity is an approximation which states that if a spring is elongated by some distance, x, the restoring force exherted by the spring, F, is proportional to x by a constant factor, k. Basically, that the extension produced is proportional to the load. That is,

F = − kx. 
When this holds, we say that the spring is a linear spring.

For many applications, a prismatic rod, with length L and cross sectional area A, can be treated as a linear spring. Its extension (strain) is linearly proportional to its tensile stress, σ by a constant factor, the modulus of elasticity, E.

For more information and diagrams:-
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hooke%27s_law

How can I calculate the volume of my trunk? Let's assume that the maximum measurments for my trunk are 38in wide, 12inches deep, and 20inches high.

I want my measurements to be in cubic feet. 

What do I do? first convert your measurements into feet.  To do this divide the inches by 12:

38 in = 38/12 ft 
12 in = 1 ft
20 in = 20/12 ft 

then calculate the volume = length * width * depth

V = (38/12)*(1)*(20/12)
V = 5.278 cubic feet

when a male horse and female donkey mates what is the offspring called?  hinny

A hinny is the offspring of a male horse and a female donkey (jennet or jenny). They are rarer than mules, which are the offspring of a male donkey (jackass or jack) and a female horse. Like the mule, the hinny is almost always sterile.

Similarities between hinnies and mules:

Hinnies are similar to mules in that they are generally more intelligent than horses, and more cooperative than donkeys. Both are also healthier and less expensive to feed and maintain than horses. This is a trait these hybrids get from their donkey heritage. The donkey is a notoriously hardy creature that, in the wild, survives on a harsh diet in a desert environment. Hinnies, like mules, also get their ability to work hard in harsh conditions from the donkey, especially in high temperatures.

Homework Help- Can you help me put these in order? Factual Answer please...

Need help putting these in order-

Vitreous humor
Aqueous humor
Ciliary Muscles
Lens
Cornea
Sclera
Iris Pupil
Retina
Choroid
Optic Nerve Cornea: The corena is a clear white thing over the outside of the eye. It helps the eye focus like a lens on a camera.

Iris: The iris is the part of your eye that has color. it gets bigger and smaller to let in different amounts of light.

Pupil: Black opening in the middle of the eye. Light comes through this opening.

Aqueous humor: The aqueous humor is clear water-like stuff that keeps your eye clean. It also provides nutrition.

Lens: The lens bends light. This helps the eye see close up and far away things.

Vitreous Humor: The vitreous humor is clear water-like stuff in the back of your eye.

Retina: The retina has nerve cells called rods and cones that detect light. It is in the back of your eye.

Optic Nerve: The optic nerve carries electrical signals from your retina to your brain so you can see.

Please tell me what is the CONJUGATE of ( 2ix - i ) and ( 1-2x )?  If z = x+iy, then the complex conjugate of z is Z'= x-iy.\nIn your sum the conjugate of 2ix - i = i(2x-1).  The real component is zero and the imaginary component is 2x-1. Then the conjugate of 2ix - i must be i(1-2x).  Similarly, \nin (1-2x) the real component is 1-2x and the imaginary component is zero.  The complex conjugate is 1-2x.

What is amber, and where is it found?  Amber is a fossil resin much used for the manufacture of ornamental objects. Although not mineralized it is sometimes considered and used as a gemstone.

The Baltic amber or succinite is found as irregular nodules in a marine glauconitic sand, known as blue earth, occurring in the Lower Oligocene strata of Sambia in Kaliningrad Oblast, where it is now systematically mined.

Although amber is found along the shores of a large part of the Baltic Sea and the North Sea, the great amber-producing country is the promontory of Samland, now part of Russia.

Amber and certain similar substances are found to a limited extent at several localities in the United States, as in the green-sand of New Jersey, but they have little or no economic value. A fluorescent amber occurs in the southern state of Chiapas in Mexico, and is used extensively to create eye-catching jewellery. Blue amber is recorded in the Dominican Republic. These Central American ambers are formed from the resins of Legume trees (Hymenea) and not conifers.

Sometimes an entire machine may be referred to as mechanism. Some examples are the steering mechanism in a car, or the winding mechanism of a wristwatch, or the mechanism of action of a drug. Optimization Problem...? An open box is to be made from a 16-inch by 30-inch piece of cardboard by cutting out squares of equal size from the four corners and bending up the sides. What size should the squares be to obtain a box with the larges volume?
Thank you! You need to find an equation first. try drawing the box out it may help. Draw a rectangle label one side 16 inches the other 30 then draw squares at each corner.

Let x be the length of one of the square's sides

Volume = length * width * height

= (30-2x) * (16- 2x) * x

=4x^(3) - 92x^(2) +480x 

Therfore  for largest volume: maximise V= 4x^(3) - 92x^(2) +480x 

To maximise: first find values of x when the first derivative is equal 0:

V ' = 12x^(2) -184x + 480 = 0

x = 12 or 3 1/3

Next verify which gives a maximum V value by either using first derivative test or second derivative test:

With first derivative test we choose values between intervals of x values for V'=0 and look at the trend:

Positive values mean the function is increasing (/) and negative values means the function is deacreasing at that point (\)

x | 0 | 3 1/3 | 5 | 12 | 14                  
V'| / .|... - .. | \. |.. - ..| /

Trend on either side of x= 3 1/3 :/\
Trend on either side of  x=12 : \/

Therefore max is at x= 3 1/3

By second derivative test :
If v"< 0 ie a negative number, V is a maximum
If v">0 ie positive number,V is a min
If V" = 0 it is a point of inflection

V"= 24x-184

x= 3 1/3,  V"= negative therefore max
x= 12 ,    V"= positive therefore min

how big is 36 square inches?  Imagine a square that is 6 inches across on each side.

That's the simplest example.

Any rectangle where the length and width have a product of 36 works also.  It can be 9 inches on one side and 4 on another.  It could even be 1 inch wide and 36 inches long (much like a yardstick).

But it's not just rectangles.  The area of a circle is pi (approx. 3.14) times the square of the radius.  So, a circle with 3.4 inches for a radius is about 36 square inches.

What are the main scientific faults with star wars?(for 8 year old school project)?  - Hipervelocity (physics): big spaceships in Star Wars can "jump into hyperspace" to move faster than light. This is forbidden by Einstein's Special Relativity.

- Sound in space (physics): you can hear spaceships, that's impossible because sounds are not transmitted by vacuum. In reality the space is completely silent.

- The Force (physics): what is it?

- Laser swords (engineering): how can they work?

- Laser guns (physics): you can see the laser beams moving from the gun to the target. Impossible for the human eye because light travels at huge speed.

- Stopping laser gun shots with laser swords (physics): Jedis are able to do this. First, due to the light speed limit, no human or device can have such fast response (the arm of the Jedi should move faster than light - impossible, see above). But even assuming that laser guns and swords exist, and that Jedis are able to do this, that would be impossible because laser beams do not interact each other. Laser gun shots would just pass through laser swords.

- Droids (engineering): it is not known whether and how their advanced Artificial Intelligence could be achieved.

How long do stars live for and why do they die?  It depends.

Red dwarfs, the smallest of stars, give off almost no light.  Because of the little energy they use, they can last trillions of years before just burning out.

Yellow dwarfs, like our sun, are different.  Like many people think, they are the ones that last billions of years before undergoing a transformation to a red giant.

Blue giants and red supergiants last the shortest.  Blue stars give off insane heat and are some of the most marvelous and brightest stars.  The cost?  They burn energy so fast, they only live for millions of years.

Either way, their fuel supply of hydrogen burns out, and have to resort to helium, expanding and cooling.  When that rns out, if the star was a red dwarf, it doesnt even expand; it cools down and fades.

If it was a yellow dwarf, it became a red giant and srunk, red giant again, planetary nebua, then became a white dwarf.  It will eventually become a black dwarf.

A super massive star runs completely out of gas.  It cant contrast, so it exploides and creates either a black hole or a neutron star in its place

what are typical types of transport across a schottky barrier?  We review theoretical interpretations of Schottky barriers and Fermi-level pinning, which result when metals and other chemical species are deposited on semiconductor surfaces. Experiments indicate that these two phenomena are closely connected, so a theory of Schottky barriers must also explain Fermi-level pinning for submonolayer coverages of both metallic and nonmetallic species. Proposed mechanisms include the following: (a) Intrinsic surface states. For GaAs and several other materials, there are no intrinsic surface states within the band gap; GaP, e.g., does have surface states in the gap, but they are not at the correct energy to explain Schottky barrier formation. (b)Metal-induced gap states. These states, which require a thick metal overlayer, cannot explain Fermi-level pinning at submonolayer metallic coverages. They also cannot explain why a single semiconductor (n-type InP) exhibits two distinct Schottky barrier heights. Furthermore, they cannot explain why the Schottky barrier persists when there is an oxide layer between semiconductor and metal. Metal-induced states can in principle give rise to Schottky barriers at defect-free interfaces, but they fail to explain much of the existing experimental data for III–V semiconductors and Si. (c) The classic Schottky model. This model is not in agreement with experiment for III–V and Group IV semiconductors, but does appear to account for the measurements involving nonreactive metals on GaSe–a layered material expected to be relatively free of defects. (d) The Spicer defect model. This phenomenological model, now supported by microscopic theoretical studies, appears to account for many of the observations regarding Schottky barrier and Fermi-level pinning. We review our theoretical investigations within the framework of the defect model, which provide a satisfactory explanation of the principal observations for both III–V and Group IV semiconductors. We conclude that the levels responsible for Schottky barriers and Fermi-level pinning arise from two sources: (1) bulk-derived deep levels (e.g., the deep donor level for the antisite defect AsGa, which persists when this defect is present at the surface, but which is shifted in energy), and (2) dangling-bond deep levels (which are also shifted in energy according to the environment of the dangling bond). Most of the observed Schottky barriers—for both III–V and Group IV semiconductors—are attributed to dangling bon

Can you project an image or movie onto a car window? I would like to know if it is POSSIBLE and, if so, how I would go about projecting a video image onto a car window from the outside of the car so the occupants can see the image.  I have a car wash and would like to be able to project promotions onto the dashboard while people are waiting.

I understand that the image will probably not be very crisp and that outside light might be a factor, but I want to know if it is possible and how I might be able to do it.  

Thank you,

Josh It is theoretically possible. If I were doing it, I would position the projector directly above the car and project down through the windshield onto the dashboard. 

In practical terms, you're going to find that this is quite difficult to make work, for the following reasons: 

(1) Dashboards are usually a dark color, which makes for a lousy projection screen. You'll need an extremely bright projector to make up for that. You'll also need extra brightness to make up for the (large!) amount of light lost due to reflection off the windshield itself, before the light even gets to the dashboard. Generally, the brighter the projector, the more expensive. Expect to pay in the five- or even six-figure range.
(2) Cars are different sizes, which means that the distance from the projection lens to the dashboard will be different in a Tahoe than in a Corolla. That means that you will need to figure out a system that can focus differently for different cars.
(3) Even knowing the throw distance to the dashboard, the dashboard is not flat. That means that parts of the image will not be in focus no matter what you do.

is pot the least lethal narcautic? less lethatl than alchol, crack, exctacy, acid...etc Pot is not a narcotic. 

Cannabis (marijuana) or hemp has been known as a medicinal and psychoactive compound from very early in history, and has been used continuously throughout the world, typically without stigma until the early 20th century, when prohibition became increasingly global.
It is generally considered to be impossible to achieve a lethal overdose by smoking cannabis. According to the Merck Index, 12th edition, the LD50, the lethal dose for 50% of tested rats, is 42 milligrams per kilogram of body weight. That is equivalent of a 75 kg (≈165 lb) man ingesting all of the THC in 21 one-gram cigarettes of maximum-potency (15% THC) cannabis buds, assuming no THC was lost through burning or exhalation. For oral consumption, the LD50 for rats is 1270 mg/kg and 730 mg/kg for males and females, respectively, equivalent to the THC in about a pound of 15% THC cannabis. Only with intravenous administration — an unheard of method of use — may such a level be even theoretically possible.

In summary, it is probably not lethal, and in moderation less harmful than repeated alcohol use.

Do pheromones really work? Sprays, perfumes, spanish fly, urine, sweat, ect..... The pheromones you are asking about are extracted from various animals ,like pigs, so I don't really understand how they would function for humans.  Pheromones are chemicals released by the body.  

In most animals pheromones are important signals for reproductive behaviors, and they may also be used to mark territories, identify individuals, and indicate aggression or submission.  Although systems of pheromones are well developed in many animals, their importance to humans is not clear.

There is one researcher that I know of named Martha McClintock.  She mainly studies the pheromones found in human females that are associated with menstrual synchrony and suppression.  The theme of her research is behavioral regulation of fertility and how social interactions (pheromones) can affect neural and endocrine function.  

I don't think that there are any human pheromones on the market, only those of animals.  In addition, each person has their own unique chemosensory communication, and pheromones are said to be odorless.

I hope this helps answer your question.  Try reading up on Martha McClintock for a more in depth understanding about human pheromones.

When the time is 3:40 What is the angle between the hands of the clock?Why?  The hour hand moves at a speed of 30 degrees per hour:

360 degrees / 12 hours = 30 degrees per hour

At 40 minutes past the hour (or 2/3 of the hour), the hour hand has moved:

30 degrees * (2/3) = 20 degrees

There is a distance of:
(30 degrees - 20 degrees = 10 degrees)

between the hour hand and the number 4.


The minute hand is pointing at the number 8.  The distance between the number 8 and number 4 is:

30 degrees * (8 - 4) = 30 degrees * 4 = 120 degrees

Add the distance of the minute hand to the distance between the hour hand and the number 4:

120 degrees + 10 degrees = 130 degrees

How and why does your face turn red when your embrassed? How and why does your face turn red when your embrassed? There is evidence that the blushing region is anatomically different in structure. The facial skin, for example, has more capillary loops per square millimeter and generally more vessels per unit volume than other skin areas. In addition, blood vessels of the cheek are wider in diameter, are nearer the surface, and visibility is less diminished by tissue fluid. These specific characteristics of the architecture of the facial vessels led Wilkin in an overview of possible causes of facial flushing to the following conclusion: "[...] increased capacity and greater visibility can account for the limited distribution of flushing" (Wilkin. 1988).\n\nEvidence for special vasodilation mechanisms was reported by Mellander and his colleagues (Mellander, Andersson, Afzelius, & Hellstrand. 1982). They studied buccal segments of the human facial veins in vitro. Unlike veins from other areas of the skin, facial veins responded with an active myogenic contraction to passive stretch and were therefore able to develop an intrinsic basal tone. Additionally Mellander et al. showed that the veins in this specific area were also supplied with beta-adrenoceptors in addition to the common alpha-adrenoceptors. These beta-adrenoceptors could exert a dilator mechanism on the above-described basal tone of the facial cutaneous venous plexus. Mellander and his colleagues propose that this mechanism is involved in emotional blushing. Drummond has partially confirmed this effect by pharmacological blocking experiments (Drummond. 1997). In a number of trials, he blocked both alpha-adrenergic receptors (with phentolamine) and beta-adrenergic receptors (with propranolol introduced transcutaneously by iontophoresis). Blushing was measured at the forehead using a dual channel laser Doppler flowmeter. Subjects were undergraduate students divided into frequent and infrequent blushers according to self-report. Their mean age was 22.9 years, which is especially favorable for assessing blushing, since young subjects are more likely to blush and blush more intensively. The subjects underwent several procedures, one of which was designed to produce blushing. Alpha-adrenergic blockade with phentolamine had no influence on the amount of blushing in frequent or in infrequent blushers, indicating that release of sympathetic vasoconstrictor tone does not substantially influence blushing. This result was expected since vasoconstrictor tone in the facial area is known to be generally low (van der Meer. 1985). Beta-adrenergic blockade with propranolol on the other hand decreased blushing in both frequent and infrequent blushers. However, despite complete blockade, blood flow still increased substantially during the embarrassment and blushing inducing procedure. Additional vasodilator mechanisms must therefore be involved. So far, no specific mechanism has been suggested.

Hardy-Weinbeg principle question! Help!? Given that genetic equilibrium demonstrated by the Hardy-Weinbeg principle only occurs under conditions that populaitons in nature seldom, if ever, experience, why is it important? 

I need Biology homework help badly! Thanks! You’re probably asking yourself why we spent so much time on HWE since it never happens in the real world. Why did I spend time on this?

It provides us with a baseline or null model to assess the impacts of different factors (each eliminated by one of the assumptions)

IE
The organism is diploid
Reproduction is sexual
Generations are non-overlapping
Mating is random
does not allow inbreeding and assortative mating
Population size is very large
removes sampling error (genetic drift)
Migration is negligible
Mutation can be ignored
Natural selection does not affect the allele in question

What is the mist cooling? If there is any picture with dimensions or details Mist cooling is simply introducing an atomized spray of water into an airstream to cool the air.   As the water droplets vaporize and dissolve in the air, they remove heat energy from the air, leaving the air slightly cooler.

These systems are most effective in dry heat climates, where the relative humidity is low.  The water can evaporate much more quickly, removing more heat.

The lowest temperature that can be conceivably reached (provided that the system were 100% efficient) is the dewpoint temperature, also known as the wet-bulb temperature.  If the air were cooled to this temperature, its relative humidity would be 100% and it would be at maximum moisture saturation.  So, in most cases, these coolers can only reduce temperatures to 60 or 70 degrees under normal conditions, unless you're in a desert or other arid region.

Most mist coolers are smaller, portable systems that use a common fan with several nozzles in front of it that produce a very fine mist spray of water.

Smaller systems are also available for cooling milling work in tooling manufacturing.  These systems typically have an additive in the water supply to reduce the oxidation effects of the water.

Does a cup of tea cool faster or a cup of milk tea? Answer with respect to entropy concepts. Let's make some assumptions:
1. The cups are the same size, shape, etc
2. The amount of hot tea is equal.
3. Both cups are in the same room at the same temperature conditions

The laws of thermodynamics state that temperatures will seek equilibrium at a rate proportional to the difference between those temperatures.

So, by adding milk to one cup, you are slightly lowering the temperature of the tea. So, the milk tea will cool at a slower rate than the other tea because the difference in room temperature and the temperature of the milk tea is less than that of the other tea. 

Final answer: cup of tea

Crop Circles and Earth Energies

If black holes exist as described then how fast would they move in the Universe?  I found this interesting article about an ancient black hole scientists have located near our solar system.  They determined the exact route and speed at which this monster has been traveling.

Conducting a bit of astronomical archaeology, researchers have dug up 43-year-old photographic evidence of an ancient black hole and used the information to learn that the object has been wandering at high speed on an odd, looping path through the Milky Way Galaxy for 7 billion years.

The study, discussed in the Sept. 13 issue of the journal Nature, represents the first measure of a black hole's movement through space, said researchers involved in the work.

The object's travels take it above and below the main plane of the galaxy, where the Sun and most other stars reside and orbit around the galactic center in relatively orderly fashion. The wayward black hole zooms along at 90 miles per second (145 kilometers per second) relative to the Earth, currently carving an arc up and over our solar system.

In pinning down the vagabond's trajectory and piecing together a picture of its past, researchers say they are adding pages to at least one chapter in the book that explains how the galaxy formed. 

The object is estimated to have been around more than 2 billion years before our Sun was born, a time when the Milky Way was a toddler of a galaxy.

"We believe that hundreds of thousands of very massive stars formed early in the history of our Galaxy, but this is the first black hole remnant of one of those huge primeval stars that we've found," said lead researcher Felix Mirabel, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Astronomy and Space Physics of Argentina and the French Atomic Energy Commission.

(a) What dimensions for the outer rectangle will require the smallest total length of fence?
(shorter side)
(longer sides)

So b = 189/l
P = 3l + 2b .. OR .. P = 2l + 3b (depending on whether the fence cutting it in half is parallel to the long side or the short side)
=  3l + 2 * 189/l .. OR .. = 2l + 3*189/l
= 3l + 378/l  .. OR .. = 2l + 567/l

So dP/dl = 3 - 378/l² .. OR .. dP/dl = 2 - 567/l²
= 0 in both cases for stationary points
ie 3 = 378/l².. OR .. 2 = 567/l²
Thus 3l² = 378 .. OR .. 2l² = 567
So l² = 196 .. OR .. l² = 283.5
So l = 14 .. OR .. l = √(567/2) = √(81*7/2) = 9/2√14 (ignoring negative results)
Thus b = 13.5 .. OR .. b = 3√14

dP²/dl = 756/l³ .. OR .. dP²/dl = 1134/l³
> 0 in both cases.
So the perimeter is minimised in both cases.

In Case 1 
length = 14m and breadth = 13.5m 
and total fencing = 3 x 14 + 2 x 13.5 
= 69m

In Case 2 
length = 9/2√14m and breadth = 3√14m 
and total fencing = 2 x 9/2√14 + 3 x 3√14 
= 18√14m
≈ 67.35m

-6x+ 5y =-2 Gauss Jordan method for this:

| 6 -5 | 4 |
| -6 5 | -2 |

R1/6 -> R1
| 1 -5/6 | 2/3 |
| -6 5 | -2 |

6R1 + R2 -> R2
| 1 -5/6 | 2/3 |
| 0 0 | 2 |

What is the "cultural context" and how does it influence development? This is dealing with developmental psychology. At birth, the brain has many synapses (connection points between neurons, where a neorutransmitter is released from one cell to signal the next).  The synapses are generated in utero by mechanisms that are primarily genetic, and they don't manage to do much to make the brain useful initially.  As a child develops, the experiences of life--which can be as simple as moving a muscle and feeling which appendage moves, or as comlex as trying to ascertain emotion from facial expression--synapses are strengthened or weakened (or even eliminated) in such ways as to make the connections that exist meaningful.  By this, I mean to say that the connections must work to potentiate a relevant response to a given stimulus.

As a stimulus-response mechanism, the brain is very complicated.  A stiulus can be internal from the brain, and a response can be internal to the brain, in terms of a cognition (thought) being either a stimulus or a response in and of itself.

Cultural context will shape the sorts of stimuli encountered and affect the way that the brain wires itself.  One of the most obvious ways is in the recognition of phonemes, or sounds that comprise a language.  Even at a very young agae, prior to the age necessary to speak, the brain is picking up cues from conversations as to what sorts of sounds are considered equal.  A given letter pronounced by one person might be very different from that pronounced by another person, but the brain will learn to regard them as the same.  A noted example of this is the letters L and R in English, which are often indistinguishable to Japanese speakers.  Others include things like the differences between Arabic single and double letters, which has no direct equivalent in English.

The cultural context will also determine many other things, particularly aesthetics.  Foods are seen as tasty or repulsive on a largely cultural basis.  Music that might be dissonant or cacophonic to some might be harmonious or rhythmic to others.

There are also the ethical differences.  For some, even uttering the wrong word might be anathema, while for others a word is just a word.  Taboos and sins will shape the brain to avoid some behaviors, while differences in virtues will predispose the mind to seek out other behaviors.

What are two types of flanges?  Are you talking about sealing surfaces or welded connections?

For sealing surfaces you have raised face flanges that can use a flat gasket or a spiral wound gasket. There are  flanges with grooved faces that use a soft oval shaped iron ring. These are usually just called ring joint flanges. Tongue and groove flanges are also available.You can also get flat faced flanges (typically for water and other low pressure services) that can use a rubber or asbestos like gasket.

The connection of the flange to the pipe can be butt weld, socket weld, slipon, or threaded.

How can global warming be reversed?  Can global warming be reversed? It has been argued that so-called clean technology may be the answer. Scrubbing flue gases from power stations will certainly remove a considerable amount of sulphur dioxide and particulate matter, but nothing can remove carbon dioxide from the environment except to return it to a form of carbon, which would consume more energy than that usefully released during combustion. The same arguments apply to "clean" car engines. The reality is that international capitalism is inextricably linked to cheap oil-based technology and as George W. Bush has amply demonstrated, is incapable, at least for the foreseeable future, of dealing with the problem of global warming. Unfortunately time is not on our side. Fossil and ice core records indicate that the current level of atmospheric CO2 is associated with considerably higher global temperatures than we are currently experiencing. The latest IPCC report also predicts a long term continuation of global warming even if CO2 emissions ceased immediately. We are likely to be in a time lag where the effects of current CO2 levels have not yet fully materialised.

Why do kettles go quite when they come to the boil? Why are kettles noisy as they come to the boil and then go quiet when they are boiling? "...it's caused by cavitation, which is a high-tech way of saying bubbles form and then they pop. When you heat water on the stove, the layer at the bottom is the first to boil, meaning it turns into a gas. The water vapor collects into bubbles, which rise toward the surface, passing through cooler water en route. The lower temperature causes the vapor to recondense into liquid and the bubbles collapse, making a noise. This gets gradually louder, as bubble production increases, until the water is so uniformly hot that the bubbles make it to the top without popping. At this point the noise diminishes. But it takes a moment before the vapor pressure builds up sufficiently in the top of the kettle to make it start whistling. That's why you get a brief period of calm before the steam--an incredibly feeble play on words, but a perfectly adequate description of the event."

If I was able to colonize a portion of space with oxygen, would the sky still be black when sunlight passes? I do not intend to suggest filling the entire vacuum of outer space.  I am just asking if I was somehow able to “colonize” a tiny portion of outer space with oxygen, would the “sky” still be black or would it be blue like it is here on Earth? If you were able to create an Earth-like atmosphere on a planet, then it would scatter sunlight just as Earth's does and the sky would be blue and bright when the sun was on it. If you just have a pressurized dome (a more technologically feasible situation), there wouldn't be enough air to significantly scatter light and you could look out of the dome and see black sky.

CRP is a protein found in the blood. It is a marker for inflammation, meaning its presence indicates a heightened state of inflammation in the body. Inflammation is a normal response to many physical states including fever, injury and infection, and is now believed to play a role in the initiation and progression of cardiovascular disease.

IGA:A type of immunoglobulin present in blood and body secretions which may aid in fighting infections.

IGG: One of many antibodies present in blood serum which is usually indicative of a recent or remote infection. IgG is most prevalent about 3 weeks after an infection begins.

Which graphs have a vertex of (0,0)? Explain how you know.? The graphs are y=3x(squared)-4, y=-2x(squared), y=5x(squared)
When i mean explain how I mean  where in the equation does it tell you that it will have a vertex of (0,0)? Please help me. The first two answers are completely wrong. The fact that (0, 0) satisfies the equation only means (0, 0) is a point on the parabola, not that it is also the vertex of the parabola. For example, plugging (0, 0) into y = (x - 1)^2 - 1 yields a true equation because the point is on the graph, but the vertex of the parabola is the point (1, -1)!

Remember that if you have a function y = f(x), then y = f(x - k) for some constant k is just the graph of f(x) shifted k units to the right (see what happens to f(k) and f(0) when you subtract k from the argument).
Similarly y = f(x) + j will be the graph of f(x) shifted upwards by j units.
Now, a parabola with vertex at the origin has function f(x) = hx^2 for some scaling constant h. The forms we are looking for are then y = h(x - k)^2 + j where the vertex will have been moved to (k, j). Thus, we just need to adjust our equations to the form above and read (k, j) off of them.
For example, your first equation is y = 3x^2 - 4. Adjusted to the form above, we get y = 3(x - 0)^2 + (-4). Thus (k, j) = (0, -4), so this graph's vertex is not at the origin.

how are thunderstorms and tornadoes related? how are thunderstorms and tornadoes alike Thunderstorms are often caused by the same conditions that tornadoes need to form. When there is a temperature inversion, where a mass of hot air is trapped under a mass of cold air, the hot air wants to rise and the cold air wants to sink. When something called a 'discontinuity' or 'catastrophe' occurs, the air masses begin to slip and spiral past one another, with the hot air rising and the cold air sinking. When the whirling air reaches the ground, it sucks up everything in its path.  Thunderstorms often happen when hot and old air masses collide. Friction between the moving air masses causes sparks of static electricity (lightning) and air currents in the clouds sometimes lift ice particles up and down over and over again so that they pick up more droplets of moisture which freeze on them and that is how hailstones grow. When the air masses collide, one can start to ride up over the other one, leading to the temperature inversion mentioned earlier.

why freon is used as refrigerant?  In Depth

During the mid-twentieth century, Freon® was little appreciated but indispensable. The DuPont-produced gas made widespread use of refrigerators and air conditioners possible and served as propellant in aerosol sprays of all types. Up to the 1920s, most commonly used refrigerants were exceedingly hazardous substances. Late in the decade, two scientists doing research for General Motors’ (GM) Frigidaire subsidiary, developed an inert, nontoxic, and odorless replacement chlorofluorocarbon gas (CFC) called Freon® . GM asked DuPont to develop the product on a large scale and a plant was built at Deepwater, New Jersey, in 1930. In their work with the substance, DuPont scientists discovered that Freon® also made an effective aerosol propellant. Related CFCs also proved effective as degreasing agents and as the basis for Teflon® , a remarkably durable and inert plastic. Freon® products were produced and marketed through a joint DuPont-GM venture called Kinetic Chemicals Company up to 1949 when the operations came under control of the Organic Chemicals Department.

Demand for Freon® refrigerants and propellants continued to grow until the 1970s when scientific studies indicated that CFCs were depleting the ozone layer that shielded the earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation. During the 1980s DuPont began developing more environmentally friendly hydroflourocarbons, eventually marketed as Suva® refrigerants and Dymel® propellants. During the 1980s, federal regulatory agencies banned the use of chlorofluorocarbons and DuPont began phasing out production, producing its last CFCs in the developed countries in 1995. The difficulties faced by American producers and consumers alike in curtailing their use of Freon® were a testament to its profound impact on postwar life.

Cause and effect of continued lost of biological diversity?  Do you mean in humans? Loss of biological diversity in humans is caused in part by genetic drift. Genetic drift is a random loss of genetic material, particularly in smaller populations. Genetic drift doesn't seem to occur in larger populations because there's no selective mating, and alleles are getting thrown around all the time. I heard somewhere that within the next 200 years or so, blondes will disappear because it is a recessive allele. I think that's bull considering the large amount of people with blonde hair, and heterozygous brunettes, but no matter.

The effect of loss of biological diversity... well I guess that depends. In selective breeding of dogs, breeders notice that they can get good results within the first few generations. For example, if they want really big dobermans, they'll mate two big dobermans, and then mate their largest offspring with other large dogs. After several generations, they'll notice that they can't make the dogs any larger because there's no more variation in size. Because they've been artificially selected, the "big" genes are all that's left, and there's no chance for "bigger" genes because there's no gene flow. (Gene flow is just the introduction of new genes into a population)

or, p + Pi/2 - p + Pi/2 over Sqrt[q^2 - p^2]

or, p-p+Pi/Sqrt[q^2 - p^2]


or, Pi/Sqrt[q^2 - p^2].

Why is it unlikely that towering clouds will form at a warm front?  Warm fronts usually have stratus clouds and the kind of widespread precip associated with them because the slope of the warm front is smaller than that of a cold front.  This means the cold front can act as a lifting mechanism for such towering cumulus clouds whereas on a warm front, because of the small slope, air won't be lifted as high and clouds won't form as high.

In this reaction, how many moles of HCl are needed to react with 2.4 moles of Al? 2 Al + 6 HCl= 2 AlC3 + 3 H2\n\nPlease explain. The coefficient before the aluminum is 2 and before hydrochloric acid is 6.  Therefore, there is a 2:6 ratio (or 1:3 if you reduce) between the reactants.  This means for every one mole of Al you will need three times as much HCl.  Thus, if you have 2.4 moles Al, you will need at least 7.2 moles of HCl.

a plane who comes from europ travels in the converse direction of the earth movement why dont spend half time?  No matter what course an aircraft takes, it is flying in the atmosphere, which rotates with the earth. It is possible to find a jetstream at high altitude, and it will speed your flight if it's in the direction you're traveling. Jetstreams generally flow eastward (same direction as earth's rotation) and can hit speeds of 275 mph (see ref.). Since this is against the Europe-to-America direction, it's unlikely that a jetstream would help such a flight.\nEDIT: The original ref. (now marked [1]) is currently unavailable, but I'm leaving it here because it had an excellent illustration of equatorial-polar convection cells. Ref. 2 has a good graphic of jet stream formation.

What does "2-3 bars steam pressure" mean?  1 Bar is defined as 14.5 PSI (pound-force per square inch). Standard atmospheric pressure is measured at sea level and some standard temperature, and is taken as 14.7 PSI.  The BAR scale uses the 14.5 PSI as the standard sea level pressure.  So 2 bar = 29 psi, where 2 standard atmospheres would equal 29.4 psi.  The errors are small at pressures near the standard 1 atmosphere as 14.7 PSI.  \n\nSteam is not really important to the question of pressure.  Pounds per square inch applies to liquids, solids, and gases.

Why exactly does sugar makesome people "hyper"? Sugar is really a pretty simple molecule.  What exactly is it that produces the effect of hyperness in some people? 

 I never see people with diabetes or blood sugar problems act "hyper", it's usually just in young children (especially those prone to ADD / ADHD) A sudden increase in blood glucose concentration leads to the release of a specific hormone in the human body: insulin. Insulin is released to reduce the concentration of sugar in the blood. In order to do this, it promotes muscular uptake of sugar, by promoting muscular activity.  

This is why people with diabetes do not show this phenomenon. Type I diabetes patients do not secrete insulin (hence the need for insulin shots). Type II diabetes patients have modified receptors that prevent insulin from being recognized by the muscle cell.

what is a fourth generation anti-hcv immunoassay? innogenetics anti-hcv fourth generation assay, elisa It's a way of testing for and measuring Hepatitis C in the blood. The lab tests available have become better over the years, and each successive test is termed the next "generation".\n\nELISA stands for enzyme linked immunosorbent assay. You start with an antibody directed against Hep C, and bind it to a well in a plate. You can then add the patients serum, remove the excess, and wash well. If the Hep C antigen was present in the serum, it's now attached to the plate via the antibody. You next add another antibody specific for Hep C which has a covalently attached enzyme (commonly beta galactosidase). If the Hep C antigen is present, the new antibody will bind as well. After washing out unbound antibody, a chemical is added (such as X-gal) which changes color if the enzyme linked antibody is present. This color change signifies the presence of the Hep C antigen in the original serum.

why do dreams occur?  there are several reasons. dreams are the bodies internal check system. when the body goes into REM sleep, the body runs a diagnostic on the body to make sure everything is in working order. while this is occuring the brain needs to occupy the person, so they dream. 

this also serves to release stress by dreaming of images that the person is dealing with. the person may go through thoughs, feelings, events that have occured to them; working out problems and emotional strain or bringing to surface issues and/or problems that the person is facing. 

the trick to dreaming is that the brain cannot tell the difference between what it sees and what it remembers. in essence, what we see in our dreams is just as real to us as what we see with our eyes. the brain does not make a distinction.

excerpt:
Probably no other individual feature of Horry County has been as important to the history and development of the area as the Waccamaw River. In 1734 Kingston Township was first surveyed with the town of Kingston (later to become Conway) as its center. The importance of Kingston was its access to the Waccamaw River and through Winyah Bay to the shipping lanes of the Atlantic. Rafting logs on the Waccamaw River required stamina and skill to snake the long rafts of freshly cut cypress and native pines to the great saw mills on the river. Rafters would live on the rafts, building shelters during cold weather and even cooking their meals on the floating logs.

the describtion of thermodynamic process? such as isobaric ,isothemic ,and isovolumetric Thermodynamics, field of physics that describes and correlates the physical properties of macroscopic systems of matter and energy. The principles of thermodynamics are of fundamental importance to all branches of science and engineering.

A central concept of thermodynamics is that of the macroscopic system, defined as a geometrically isolable piece of matter in coexistence with an infinite, unperturbable environment. The state of a macroscopic system in equilibrium can be described in terms of such measurable properties as temperature, pressure, and volume, which are known as thermodynamic variables. Many other variables (such as density, specific heat, compressibility, and the coefficient of thermal expansion) can be identified and correlated, to produce a more complete description of an object and its relationship to its environment.

When a macroscopic system moves from one state of equilibrium to another, a thermodynamic process is said to take place. Some processes are reversible and others are irreversible. The laws of thermodynamics, discovered in the 19th century through painstaking experiment, govern the nature of all thermodynamic processes and place limits on them.

What is the temperature of steam(fresh water)compared to the temperature of steam from salt water? Since the boiling point of salt water is higher than the boiling point of salt water, therefore my guess is that the temperature of salt water steam is higher than fresh water steam. The highest temperature water in liquid form can reach is the boiling point.  At this point the water will change from a liquid phase to a gas.  For pure water, this initial temperature is 100 deg Celcius.  For salt water, the  water will reach about 100.5 deg before turning into a gas.  Once it becomes a gas it usually escapes direct contact from the heat source and cools and condenses back into a liquid form that is suspended in the air in the form of tiny droplets (this is the steam that you see).  Since any salt will remain behind as the liquid boils into a gas, the gaseous water from both sources will condense back into the steam that you see at 100 degrees.  So I guess you could say that the initial temperature of boiling water from salt water is slightly higher but once it becomes the white misty steam that you see, the two are basically the same temperature.

\GRAVITY //  How does it works?  Okay. Everything that has mass has gravity. You and I have our own innate gravity. So does your pencil, your computer, the air you breathe. 

If you think of space-time (see Einstein) as the surface of a huge trampoline on which everything sits, then mass sits on top of that trampoline. But if you put a bowling ball on a trampoline, it puckers the surface and smaller things are drawn towards it, and it is drawn towards the smaller thing, if only a little bit. Similarly, if you roll a marble around the bowling ball, it will circle many times before it finally crashes into the bowling ball. (That how orbiting works.)

This is simplified, of course, but it helps to understand the concepts. If you are interested in the subject, I would recommend reading Billions and Billions by Carl Sagan.

Good Luck!

Define matter,mass,particle,wave,space,atom,element,molecule,antimatter? I know only mathematics where we start with axioms and then only we can define anything. In physics,what is the starting point?Are there basic axioms? The definations wanted by you are given below-

In physics, matter is commonly defined as the substance of which physical objects are composed, not counting the contribution of various energy or force-fields, which are not usually considered to be matter per se (though they may contribute to the mass of objects). Matter constitutes much of the observable universe, although again, light is not ordinarily considered matter. Unfortunately, for scientific purposes, "matter" is somewhat loosely defined.

Mass is a property of a physical object that quantifies the amount of matter and energy it is equivalent to. Mass is a central concept of classical mechanics and related subjects, and there are several forms of mass within the framework of relativistic kinematics (see mass in special relativity and mass in General Relativity). In the theory of relativity, the quantity invariant mass, which in concept is close to the classical idea of mass, does not vary between single observers in different reference frames.

An elementary particle is a particle with no measurable internal structure, that is, it is not a composite of other particles. They are the fundamental objects of quantum field theory. Elementary particles can be classified according to their spin, with fermions having half-integer spin and bosons integer spin.

Space has been an interest for philosophers and scientists for much of human history. The term is used somewhat differently in different fields of study, hence it is difficult to provide an uncontroversial and clear definition outside of specific defined contexts. Disagreement also exists on whether space itself can be measured or is part of the measuring system. (See Space in philosophy.) Many fields use an operational definition in which the units of measurement are defined, but not space itself.

In chemistry and physics, an atom (Greek  átomos meaning "indivisible") is the smallest particle of a chemical element that retains its chemical properties. 

A chemical element, often called simply an element, is a substance that cannot be decomposed or transformed into other chemical substances by ordinary chemical processes. All matter consists of these elements and as of 2006, 117 unique elements have been discovered or artificially created. The smallest particle of such an element is an atom, which consists of electrons centered about a nucleus of protons and neutrons.

In chemistry, a molecule is an aggregate of two or more atoms in a definite arrangement held together by chemical bonds. Chemical substances are not infinitely divisible into smaller fractions of the same substance: a molecule is generally considered the smallest particle of a pure substance that still retains its composition and chemical properties. Certain pure substances (e.g., metals, molten salts, crystals, etc.) are best understood as being composed of networks or aggregates of atoms or ions instead of molecular units.

In particle physics, antimatter extends the concept of the antiparticle to matter, wherein if a particle and its antiparticle come into contact with each other, the two annihilate —that is, they may both be converted into other particles with equal energy in accordance with Einstein's equation E = mc2. This gives rise to high-energy photons (gamma rays) or other particle–antiparticle pairs-.

why do we see upside down through raindrops?  My vision isn't good enough to actually "look" through a raindrop, but I understand your question.  Raindrops are a lot like a lens.  In fact, a raindrop is a lens.  Every lens has a focal length based on its shape and material and when objects within the focal length, they are magnified.  Raindrops, however, have a very short focal length so anything you see through them will likely be beyond the focal length.  Objects beyond the focal length are not necessarily magnified, and in fact they are flipped.  It's much easier to understand with a ray tracing diagram.  I've provided a link to the slides my professor used in his optics lecture.  Slide 5 in particular should be of help.

f  :  Z  → R. If  f(n)=f(n+11)=f(n+18) for all n in Z then show f is a constant function?  If f(n) = f(n + 11) = f(n + 18) then
f(n) = f(n + c1 * 11) = f(n + c2 * 18) is also true,
because f(n) = f(n + 11) = f(n + 11 + 11) = f(n + 11 + 11 + 11) etc.
so f(n + 1) = f(n + 1 + c1 * 11)
for c1 = 13 we get:
f(n + 1) = f(n + 1 + 13 * 11)
f(n + 1) = f(n + 144) = f(n + 8 * 18) =>
f(n + 1) = f(n) for every n in Z, so f(n) has to be a constant.

How can a bullet be traced to a particular gun?  A bullet can not really be "traced" to a particular gun but it can be matched with other bullets fired from the same weapon. Most ballistic experts will be able to ascertain the type of gun a bullet was fired from by the bullet type and other characteristics. They can't match a bullet to a gun however until they have the gun in their own hands. \nAt which time they test fire the gun into water or gel and then recover the bullets. It is at this time, that under a microscope they can match the markings on the two bullets. These come from the inside of the gun barrel which is not microscopically smooth.

biology question...plz help!!? oki need to know all the body systems that are related to rosacea... u no like the nervous system and stuf.. and after that i need all the organs involved..ty so much There are four identified rosacea subtypes[1] and patients may have more than one subtype present.
Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea: Permanent redness (erythema) with a tendency to flush and blush easily. It is also common to have small blood vessels visible near the surface of the skin (telangiectasias) and possibly burning sensations.
Papulopustular rosacea: Some permanent redness with red bumps (papules) with some pus filled (pustules), this subtype can be easily confused with acne.
Phymatous rosacea: This subtype is most commonly associated with rhinophyma, an enlargenent of the nose. Symptoms include thickening skin, irregular surface nodularities, and enlargement. Phymatous rosacea on appear on the nose, chin, forehead, cheeks, and ears. Small blood vessels visible near the surface of the skin (telangiectasias) may be present.
Ocular rosacea: Red, dry and irritated eyes and eyelids. Some other symptoms include foreign body sensations, itching and burning.
 
for more information visit

obtain common salt from rock salt? Rock salt contains some insoluble impurities such as sand and clay. I want to know how to obtain pure common salt from rock salt. Do not crush the rock salt as this will make the impurities harder to remove.

Dissolve the rock salt in very hot water and filter.  If the filtrate (the water that comes through the filter) is colored, then you might need to treat it with charcoal to remove these soluble impurities.

Once you have a clear solution, allow some of the water to evaporate until the solution becomes saturated.  A single seed crystal will start the formation of sodium chloride crystals from the solution.  Stirring will keep the crystals smaller, otherwise you can end up with one very large crystal of salt.

This crystallization process is what does the final purification.  The crystals formed will be almost pure sodium chloride.

why doesnt water burn? h2o has a stable oxygen atom, when heated gets converted to steam. hydrogen gas burns so why doesnt steam? VTNomad is right.  Hydrogen gas is H:H (two hydrogen atoms sharing a covalent bond) and molecular oxygen is O=O (two oxygen atoms sharing two covalent bonds).

Oxidation results from electronegativity, or the affinity of atoms for electrons.  Oxygen is very electronegative, which means it really, really wants to have it's own electrons, and it hates to share them (metaphorically speaking, of course).  Hydrogen is not very electronegative, and its pretty content to walk around as a positive ion with no electrons at all.  It is the weakling on the school playground who will get beaten up and have its electrons stolen by the big kids, like oxygen and chlorine.

Two oxygen atons don't like having to share electrons, but they can't take them from one another.  But if an oxygen molecule sees two hydrogen molecules, then the two oxygen atoms will part ways, and each will beat up the hydrogen weakling and take both of its electrons.  The "fight" that ensues is fire, where the rapid loss of energy (O=O bonds and H-H bonds have a lot of energy, while H-O-H bonds are low in energy) becomes heat and light, aka fire.

An oxygen atom, though it likes electrons, will have a negative charge of -2 if it has the eight total electrons needed for Nobel configuration.  Likewise, Hydrogen will have a positive charge if denied its electrons.  So oxygen will let two little hydrogens tag along, and the H2O molecule is charge neutral.  But in water, the electrons are almost always around the oxygen, while the hydgrogen has very little chance of any electrons being around it for very long.  These bonds are low energy.

Other things that burn--coal, gas, methane--these are things where carbon shares electrons with either more carbon or with hydrogen.  O2 will come along and steal electrons.  But O2 can't steal electrons from water, because the oxygen atom in water is just as tough (electronegative) as the oxygen in O2, so it won't win that fight.  But oxygen can take electrons from carbon (giving CO2, or carbon dioxide) or hydrogen, and it does.

Alot of Chinese and Japanese have really light skin, yet NONE have naturally blonde or brown hair.? It is always either black or dark dark brown. Same for eyes, dark brown, or black. Why is it so common in Europe to see a group of people with vast different hair colors and eye colors? To have a sudden trait pop up out of nowhere is called a mutation. Because your mother had a nose and your father had a nose, and these noses were in their genetic code, YOU have a nose. No surprise there, right?\nCertain regions of the world are going to have certain traits (dark skin, light hair, blue eyes, taller structure, etc) because that is simply what is passed down to them. If you had the lightest blond hair and had children in Japan with a Japanese woman, there is a CHANCE that your children would have light hair too. But your grandchildren will have darker hair... and great grands darker still. After a few generations your blond hair genes will have dissipated into the black hair genes that surround you.\n(This is why certain countries like the U.S. are called "melting pots": so many genes mixing together that you can have all kinds of results.)
